docs.lead_paragraph: Thick debate surrounds the Yankees and their place of residence, of the present and the future, but the players are insulated from this. David Szen, the team's traveling secretary, arranges the itinerary and shepherds them all from one field to the next, whether in Detroit or Toronto. The Yankees, a flock comprised mostly of veterans, proceed without a bleat of protest. Rather, they intently feast on the rest of the American League. The way they're playing -- 11 victories in their last 12 games -- whatever is in front of them probably looks good. But the Yankees will recognize their surroundings tonight when they play the Detroit Tigers in grand old Yankee Stadium, inspected and repaired.

headline.main: All Seems Normal, For Now, In Bronx

docs.abstract: New York Yankees to face Detroit Tigers in inspected and repaired Yankee Stadium (M)
docs.snippet: Thick debate surrounds the Yankees and their place of residence, of the present and the future, but the players are insulated from this. David Szen, the team's traveling secretary, arranges the itinerary and shepherds them all from one field to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since 1992, many employers are facing double-digit increases in the cost of their health insurance next year, the highest inflation rate since the majority of employees moved into managed care. In early negotiations with employers about next year's rates, many insurers are seeking increases for 1999 far above this year's, when most premiums rose in single digits after four years of stability.

headline.main: HEALTH INSURERS SEEK BIG INCREASES IN THEIR PREMIUMS

docs.abstract: Many employers, for first time since 1992, are facing double-digit increases in cost of their health insurance next year--highest inflation rate since majority of employees moved into managed care; insurers are seeking increases for 1999 that are far above this year's, when most premiums rose in single digits after four years of stability; critics of managed care say magnitude of increases undercuts basic appeal behind managed care: savings from lower costs; 85 percent of American employees were enrolled in managed-care plans in 1997; benefits consultants estimate that increases will average about 7 percent nationally, or five times current 1.4 percent consumer inflation rate; Kaiser Permanente is seeking 12 percent increase from large employers in California (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about a freeze in rates for many New Yorkers who buy their own health insurance misstated the date of the state law requiring health maintenance organizations to offer coverage to individuals. It was 1992, not 1996.
docs.abstract: Correction on April 22 article about freeze in rates for many New Yorkers who buy their own health insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's physicians still complain that managed care organizations drown them in paperwork and meddle with their prerogatives in treating patients. But their fears for their own livelihoods, that managed care would reduce their wages or drive them out of medicine, are proving overdrawn. Doctors' incomes have rebounded from the nearly 4 percent decline four years ago that was reported by the American Medical Association in early 1996. That decrease was widely attributed to the impact of managed care. A survey of 1996 incomes, which was reported just last month, showed physicians' average earnings rising to the threshold of $200,000 for the first time.

headline.main: Doctors' Pay Regains Ground Despite the Effects of H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Doctors fears that managed care would reduce their earnings or drive them out of medicine are proving to be unfounded; doctors' incomes have rebounded from nearly 4 percent dip four years ago; survey shows doctors' average earnings rose to nearly $200,000 for first time in 1996, up $18,000 from 1994 and up $70,000 from 1987, when managed care was just beginning to spread; doctors are no longer realizing 10 percent annual income gains they saw in old days of fee-for-service medicine, when they could essentially bill insurance companies whatever they wished; income changes have often been volatile in some specialities; graphs; table (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: On a snowy night in January 1996, a handful of Boston scientists convened some of the city's most prominent Jews for a quiet, off-the-record briefing. Over sandwiches and cookies, the rabbis and leaders of Jewish groups learned of the latest research on a breast cancer gene that occurs with startling frequency in American Jews of Central and Eastern European descent. Then Dr. Judy Garber, a breast cancer researcher at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, posed a question to the guests: Would their organizations cooperate in future studies of this gene and its implications for these Jews, called Ashkenazis, and their families?

headline.main: Concern Among Jews Is Heightened As Scientists Deepen Gene Studies

docs.abstract: American Jews are conflicted about increasing scientific interest in studying genetic idosyncracies of Ashkenazi Jews; Ashkenazis, descended from Jews who lived and married for centuries within confines of Central and Eastern European ghettoes, are relatively homogenous population in which tiny genetic mutations that cause disease are easy to find; do not have higher rates of hereditary disease than other groups; other isolated populations are being studied with similar intensity, but less controversy; researchers hold studies offer Jews early access to genetic testing and, eventually, treatment; others fear they will leave Jews vulnerable to discrimination by employers and insurance companies and create false view of Jews as genetic misfits; Hadassah is sponsoring conference in which National Institutes of Health aides will discuss research with rabbis and Jewish leaders; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Pataki administration announced yesterday that it would bar health insurance companies from raising rates this year for tens of thousands of New Yorkers who buy their own health insurance, saying the state would turn over $110 million to the companies to offset costs. The move sidesteps huge rate increases -- which would affect many of the state's sickest people -- being proposed in the thick of an election year by several of the state's largest insurers.

headline.main: ALBANY WILL PAY HEALTH INSURERS TO FREEZE RATES

docs.abstract: New York State Insurance Supt Neil D Levin denies huge rate increases sought by Oxford Health Plans and Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield for people who buy own health insurance; says NY will instead pay $110 million collected during last several years from insurers to Oxford, Empire and other insurers to offset future increases for individual premiums; advocates for sick and poor laud plan; some insurers and Democrats score Gov Pataki for holding back money until election year, holding it should have been paid out to insurers long ago; critics cite need for long-term solution (M)
